title: How to Store Toilet Paper in Decorative Ways

methods.name: Size Up Your Area and Design

steps.headline: Determine where you could possibly keep the toilet paper.
steps.description: Don't worry about how you will store it, just locate an area near the commode, shower or sink that could possibly be turned into a small storage area. Remember--storage doesn't mean it has to sit on the ground either.

steps.headline: Identify your overall bathroom design.
steps.description: How your bathroom is decorated will most likely dictate the kind of storage you will end up using. For example, if you have a lot of crystal and white towels, you may want to consider a clear vase or jar for the T.P. However, if animal prints or a wilder style is more your taste, you could get funkier and create a small print hammock for your supplies.

steps.headline: Decide which type of storage will work best with your personality/schedule.
steps.description: Even though replacing toilet paper is one of the easiest “chores” at home, some people simply don't do it. Make sure that the storage system you select is something that you will easily maintain  and keep up.

methods.name: Create a Hanging System for Smaller Spaces

steps.headline: Design a toilet paper hammock.
steps.description:
Purchase fabric to match your bathroom décor (long and wide enough to hold one or even two rolls of toilet paper) and decorative ribbon. steps.headline: Place the toilet paper in the middle of the fabric and then tie the ribbon to the toilet paper holder.
Mount a small shelf above the toilet to store supplies.
steps.description: You can purchase small shelving at the local hardware store you can make your own using steel brackets and plywood.

steps.headline: Design an “over the toilet tank” toilet paper holder.
steps.description: Create a toilet paper dispenser with two hooks that hang off the side of the toilet. Design this storage system similar to the toilet paper hammock, just use hooks instead of ribbon.

steps.headline: Use a decorative basket filled with toilet paper located next to the toilet.
steps.description: Find a basket in a size that won't interfere with traffic patterns but one that is easily accessed from the loo.

steps.headline: Maintain toilet paper inside a decorative canister or clear glass vase.
steps.description: This method may hold up to three or possibly four rolls (depending on the size) at once. Keep near the toilet or behind the tank.

steps.headline: Design a holder from an old CD or DVD package.
steps.description: The top of a box of DVDs or CDs is the perfect size to hold a reserve roll of T.P. House it on the floor or the tank for quick access.

steps.headline: Repurpose an old vintage hat to hold extra toilet paper.
steps.description: Simply tip the hat upside down and place rolls inside. If possible, go for a larger hat for better storage.

You can purchase small shelving at the local hardware store you can make your own using steel brackets and plywood. Design an “over the toilet tank” toilet paper holder. Create a toilet paper dispenser with two hooks that hang off the side of the toilet. Design this storage system similar to the toilet paper hammock, just use hooks instead of ribbon. Floor Storage Use a decorative basket filled with toilet paper located next to the toilet. Find a basket in a size that won't interfere with traffic patterns but one that is easily accessed from the loo. Maintain toilet paper inside a decorative canister or clear glass vase. This method may hold up to three or possibly four rolls (depending on the size) at once. Keep near the toilet or behind the tank. Design a holder from an old CD or DVD package. The top of a box of DVDs or CDs is the perfect size to hold a reserve roll of T.P. House it on the floor or the tank for quick access. Repurpose an old vintage hat to hold extra toilet paper. Simply tip the hat upside down and place rolls inside. If possible, go for a larger hat for better storage.
